description.text:
A print to assist with leveling your bed.

Directions
1) Open in customizer and set layerHeight and layerWidth to match your current setup.
2) Set distanceFromCenter to a number around 20% of your print bed size. On a 200x200mm bed, use around 40.
3) Adjust the other settings if you wish.
4) Create the STL and download it, and prepare it for printing.
5) Check that the printer is ready and build platform is mostly level.
6) Print the test you created.
7) Examine the result and adjust the level. See the tips below.
8) If the print was perfect, print your model. Otherwise go back to step 6.

Tips

  • Issues which could mean the bed is too low:
    • Gaps in the first layer.
    • Corners or edges peeling up.
    • Complete failure to stick to bed.
  • Issues which could mean the bed is too high:
    • No filament extruded/missing peices.
    • Layer is not smooth/has bumps and lines.
    • Leaves a trail of filament between pieces.
  • Also compare the thickness of the pieces from side to side and corner to corner. You want them to be as close as possible.
  • Remember that when you adjust a screw, it changes the whole bed. Make sure to counter balance as you adjust. For example, if one side is high and the opposite side is perfect, I will adjust the high side down and then the opposite side up about 1/2 the amount I adjusted the high side.
  • Always use small adjustments. If you have a long print ahead of you, it is worth getting the leveling perfect.
  • Note down on your printer which way to adjust your screws. Trust me, it's worth the tiny effort
  • Make sure everything else is set before you try to level. Leveling should be the last step before a print.

title: Arduino Mouse Wiggler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It is kind of annoying every time when the computer goes into sleep, especially when you are in the middle of a PowerPoint presentation, or working from home but supposed to appear available online all the time. This simple device will wiggle (jiggle) your mouse for you every 30 seconds or so and keep your computer always awake. This device simply simulates the physical mouse movement, there's no App or driver to be installed, so it is 'stealth' and won't violate the company IT policy or expose yourself to dangerous software.

The detailed instruction is at https://www.instructables.com/id/Arduino-Mouse-Wiggler/

See how it works https://youtu.be/oT0NxThso_A

--- Description ---
This a weighted poker card capper. It is placed on your hole cards during a hand to make sure they are not accidentally folded.

This design is from a scan of a Resting Mexican sculpture.

Initially when receiving the Eachine EV100 I had a problem where I was seeing double screens so I took it all apart and found that a 2-3 degree angle on each eye piece (left one minus and right on plus) made the issue go away.

Started modelling the bottom plate so I could mount the eye piece at a 3 degree angle however it's a bit incomplete as I found someone's post that said you should focus somewhere far away, then put the goggles on which has done the trick for me so I have stopped this project, give that a try first before you try anything else.

You could use this bottom plate design as a starting off point for any EV100 projects you might have in mind.

The modelling is done in Maya and starts off with the bottom thin plate which is bevelled to give it an angle and everything else is boolean union or difference [edge] (yes I know that it's bad to use these but it's quick). Since everything is with booleans they are separate objects so you can adjust things easily.

Things missing:

  • The 4 screw pillars to hold the board in place
  • Extra support for the existing screw pillars
  • The existing screw pillars need to be checked that they exactly match where they should be and that the height is right
  • The eye piece section which the ski mask snaps into needs to be worked on
  • The right eye piece won't adjust to the left unless you mount it a bit back or remove some of the nose section
  • Printing the whole thing and re-verifying everything fits

Included is 3 Maya files, one which has the bottom thin plate only ready for the boolean cutout. The second file is everything ready for the boolean operations. The third file is everything after boolean operations. STL file is optimised using the free version of Autodesk Netfabb Premium 2017.

comments.author: bramesh501

comments.text: That version is much easier to print, but the leading edges of the vertical stabilizers are still very difficult for a printer to handle. If you print it as you oriented it in the simplify3d screenshot, most of the surfaces print well, but if you use the preview feature to see the toolpath at the forward-most part of the vertical stabilizer (the lowest layer that the vertical stabilizer starts printing on), you'll see that it starts with just a very tiny point touching the support material, not attached to the main body. It's not enough surface area to remain attached to the support unless I tweak support so that it is not removeable after printing.

Ahh, meeples. A couple of new designs for them, with numbers! Why numbers? Well, if you have eight orcs attacking the party, and you need to know if Bob the Bard just stabbed orc #3 or orc #5, the number's right there!

print_settings.Notes:: I chose a concentric external fill pattern that gave the print interesting patterns but caused over extruding between overlapping layers.

description.text: The Division logo desktop stand or wall mounted printed in two colors with a single extruder.

Printer:

CreatBot DE Plus 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.18

Infill:

15-50

Notes:

I used Simplify 3D to print this model. To print in two colors with a single extruder:

  1. I sliced the whole logo (except the stand which is printed separately).
  2. In the process setting, I stopped printing at layer 28 (after printing the back plate and support for the wings in black).
  3. Replaced the black filament with orange, and started printing at layer 29.

Stand is provided optional if you want a desktop stand for the logo, in which case the infill of the stand was 50% to be heavy enough to hold the logo.

I chose a concentric external fill pattern that gave the print interesting patterns but caused over extruding between overlapping layers.

print_settings.Notes:: Cura

description.text:
I'm not a huge fan of the captive nuts in general and this part had a bunch.
Instead I favor the brass knurled inserts.

Printer:

Hypercube

Notes:

Cura

Add Inserts

Heat up your soldering iron.
Place a knurled inset on the soldering iron hot tip. (be careful).
Transfer the insert to the printer part.
Gently push the insert into the plastic.

Be careful not to over insert, and be sure to keep straight.

80 mm Solder Fume Extractor/ Air Filter Fan Tower(s)
(80 x 80 x 25 mm and 80 x 80 x 27 mm)

Demo Video: https://youtu.be/tuqtLt2RE0s?t=6
Build Video: https://youtu.be/8f00zDafwwI
Instructable: https://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printable-Solder-Fume-Extractor-Air-Filter-the-/

This is a battery or DC adapter powered fan tower solder fume extractor/ air filter. Above carbon-filters are installed behind the fans .You can build larger towers by mixing and matching the 3D printable Top/Bottom, Mitte, and Dowels while putting them together. (See the build video)

The fans are wired in parallel so that the CFM's and Amperage used are additive. (See the Instructable for full DC circuit discussion and instructions to build.)

In the demo video, 4 x 80 mm Artic F8s fans are used in two towers, The F8s are specified at :
Air Flow: 31 CFM / 52.7 m³/h (@ 2,000 RPM)
Amperage: ~150 mAmps

So the totals:

124 CFM @ 600 mAmps plus Boost-Buck amperage usage..

In the build video, ARC .5 Amp 80 mm fans are used. They are almost e3 times more powerful than the F8s and much louder ..

The towers actually perform far better than their ratings due to the open fan/extract areas.(see Demo video)

ATTENTION: Many Fans are listed as 80x80x25 mm but when measured are often a bit wider than the specified 25 mm. I have included two additional STLs for 27mm Top/Bottom and Mitte pieces. Please measure your fans before printing to avoid an disappointment.

Regards
G.,

description.text:
The only version I could find for this (thing:2285403)wouldn't allow the camera to be mounted without using their modified frame, which looked to me as if the camera mount part would be a weak spot when 3d printed so I got busy with the broken original CF one, a vernier, and a copy of freecad.

V1 needs supports but and will only work if ALL 4 shrouds are made from this design as the camera sits slightly higher than stock....(happy accident, should have taken measurements from a good one, not the broken one, but it does make extra room for other things like an openlog......)

V2 can be mounted individually and fit while also using some of the original shrouds;
It also shouldn't need supports; Printed ook without supports for me (use a layer fan),YMMV depending on your printer setup.

title: SimpleSumo- Educational Fighting Robots!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
SimpleSumo is an awesome little open source robot which allows anyone to build their very own autonomous mini-sumo with no prior knowledge in robotics at a price that everyone can afford!

Designed with education in mind, I created the 'SimpleSumo' platform to lower the barrier to entry into the robot sport of mini-sumo.

These robots are easy enough to understand and build that kids can get started quickly, but they also offer great depth through Mr-potato-head-style mechanical customization and Arduino programming.

These toys are intended for small groups, ages 10+. Assembly takes ~1hr and requires minimal tool use and absolutely no soldering or breadboarding. Adult supervision is suggested for students who are younger than high school level.

**Complete & partial robot kits are available at this link, or you can print and gather everything yourself from scratch using these 3d printable files.
https://engineerdog-webstore.fwscart.com/

**For the full assembly instructions & up to date shopping list visit this page on Instructables.com: https://www.instructables.com/id/SimpleSumo-Educational-Fighting-Robots/

**For an up to date list of programs and where to find all things SimpleSumo, visit:
https://engineerdog.com/simplesumo

**The files included are enough to build the complete standard kit. For upgrades beyond that I chose to sell the 3d printable files in order to recoup my substantial R&D costs. They are <$3 on Pinshape.com here: https://pinshape.com/search/designs?q=simplesumo

**Video Series Introduction Link:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nb-5wq9CI20&t=41s&list=PLxT-reigvGs0wmGk_xd2I9fvHXbBV3jPA&index=3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3 or finer

Infill:

20%+

Notes:

-Must be printed in ABS or PETG, 4 perimeters all sides top & bottom, 20% infill minimum.

-The tire treads are printed in flex filament, as flexible as you are capable of printing at 100% infill.

-You must reorient the files before printing, as shown in the yellow labeled images. All files print without supports except the cover, which I recommend printing upside down with supports to reduce the sag.

description.text:
This is a Taz 6 specific variant of my existing Taz 5 Antiwobble design (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1089626) It uses the same steel pin and igus bearing design, just doubled up and eliminating the upper plate pins. it seems to work fine so far. This is the retrofit variant. A taz 6 x axis openbuilds specific variant built into the taz 6 openbuilds x motor and idler is also on the way.

Development thread here:
https://forum.lulzbot.com/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=6820&p=37920#p37920

You will need the following parts:
8 M5 heat set inserts http://www.mcmaster.com/#94180a361/=zhts4o
4 3/16" 1 and 3/4" long steel shafts (locally sourced from Ace Hardware)
4 3/16" 2" long steel shafts (locally sourced from Ace Hardware)
16 Igus 2MTRI MYI-03-03 Flanged Bearing, 3/16" IDx 3/16" L (ebay)
the stock M5 bolts
4 additional m5 bolts (probably 10mm long?)

Instructions:

  1. insert the M5 heat set nuts into the 4 holes in the upper mount.
  2. insert the Igus bearings in the grooves. you will likely need to clearance the holes for good fit.
  3. Bolt the lower piece onto the stock leadscrew mounring point in place of the leadscrew nut. Remove the green ring at that time.
  4. Push the pins into place to lock the middle section over the lower section, I find its easiest to drill out one side and partially into another to make one side of the pin insertion point a friction fit.
  5. Now install the upper section.
  6. Bolt the leadscrew nut to the new wobble mount.

Notes:
1 This is experemental and untested. I don't have a taz 6 frame to fit it to. It should fit, but it may not. If it does fit, someone please let me know.

  1. you will lose 10mm of theoretical total Z axis travel to fit this. it won't affect auto leveling or require any firmware modifications, but it does take up space in the upper section of the leadscrew.
  2. This will likely fit any 10mm leadscrew that uses a 4 bolt mount pattern without too much modification. it won't fit a taz 5 easily due to the space claim required, but you may very well be able to use this with other printers.

Installation instructions:
Taz 6 Anti wobble assembly instructions 1.0a 11/29/2017

  1. Move the Z axis to the middle of the printer area and power off the printer.
  2. Remove the Z maximum limit switch mounting bolts.
  3. Insert the Z maximum limit switch height extender and mount with the stock M2 bolts. Use two additional M2 bolts to secure the limit switch in its new extended position. This will give the leadscrew nut the necessary clearance after inserting the anti wobbles.
  4. Carefully Remove the Z axis top plate on the X motor leadscrew side.
  5. Carefully release the coupler from the leadscrew or motor side of the Z motor / leadscrew interface. If it has been secured with Loctite skip this step.
  6. Unbolt the leadscrew nut on the z Motor mount side and carefully remove the leadscrew. Also remove the Green flex washer. If the leadscrew coupler could not be removed, you may need to manually unthread the leadscrew nut by spinning it up and away from the mount. This is less desirable because you will have to reposition it later.
  7. Bolt the lower wobble nut piece to the Z X motor mount.
  8. Slide the middle anti wobble pins in place. It should require a bit of force to get them seated into the far holes. Once seated the middle wobble piece should slide back and forth smoothly and move at least 1mm.
  9. Now place the top wobble piece in position and slide its pins into place. It should also move back and forth easily and move at least 1mm in the opposite axis. The entire anti wobble assembly should have no flex up or down in the Z axis, but should be able to move freely in X and Y.
  10. Reinsert and Bolt the leadscrew nut back to the top anti wobble mount with 2-4 M5 bolts. You may omit 2 bolts if weight is a concern here.
  11. If you were able to remove the coupler, now re-attach it and ensure the setscrews are tight. If you were unable to remove the coupler, you may have to re-thread the leadscrew bolt at this point down to the approximate location it was before. In that case you will need to use calipers to ensure that the leadscrew nuts on both sides of the assembly are the same height when finished.
  12. Now repeat steps 4-11 on the Z X idler side of the printer. Doing one side at a time will minimize the possibility for significant frame position error.
  13. When both sides are re-attached, use a set of calipers to ensure that the distance from the top of the leadscrew nut to the bottom of the upper leadscrew bearing bottom surface is the same on both sides of the printer.
  14. Reattach power to the printer and turn it back on. It should be able to move the z axis up and down easily with no binding. Ensure you can safely travel the entire Z axis range with no binding slowly and carefully before proceeding with a test print.
  15. Proceed with a test print. You should now see much less visible Z offset. If you encounter any layer separation or odd layer squish patterns that were not there before, ensure that the anti-wobble is not allowing any movement in the Z axis direction and adjust accordingly to make sure the pins cannot move up or down.

print_settings.Notes:: In the photos you can see the printed part fitted to the Dyson (where the Dyson motor would usually go), one with the vac pipe to the shopvac screwed in and one without. Note, the vac pipe is a left hand thread. You'll notice a gap where the 3d part and the dyson meets, the intention is to fill this with silicone to ensure a air tight joint. I have attached the STL and GCODE file. I sliced it in Cura 2.7 with 1.6mm wall thickness. Printed in PLA at 200C and bet at 60C. The GCODE will show the orientation I used to print. Obviously you can use the STL and slice to suit your printer/material.ect.

description.text:
Part of a larger project. I have a broken Dyson full sized vac and am converting the cyclone part to fit onto my old electrolux shopvac for my woodworking tools (Table saw and Router mainly) that are mounted on a Triton 2000 worktable.

This part is so that I can screw in the electrolux pipe (40mm OD and +-5mm pitch) onto the extraction port of the top piece I removed from the dyson.

However, anywhere you want a bulkhead mounted screw in fitting for a compatible vacuum pipe, this will work fine.

Will update as the project progresses:
UPDATE 16 Oct
Added 2 parts.
1) Bulkhead mounted adapter from full sized Dyson tube clip-on connector to press-fit female adapter. This will allow the cyclonic filter to be connected via the existing Dyson pipe to a bulkhead mounted on the table.
2) Press-fit male to electrolux pipe adapter
This screws onto an Electrolux vac pipe. One short section like this is required (and permanently mounted on) each tool e.g. skill saw, Router or whatever. This fitting is simply pressed into the above bulkhead fitting when you change out a tool.

I designed and printed this as one unit, but the small retaining lip would get damaged when I pressed it onto the stud.

I split it in half and printed 2, then glued them together while holding them in place on the stud.

Notes:

PLA, was my first material, it lasted about a month. The wheel warped and failed after a 30min cycle of cooking rice. The warm water and steam that accumulated in the track of the wheel heated it up to fail point. I checked it daily and it worked until this long cycle. I added a picture of the failed PLA wheel.

ABS is the current material, still holding fingers crossed.

White Wheel = Original.
Black Wheel = Replacement.

Will update if I get more results.
It's a 3D scan of a female deer skull.

Connecting the power line to the usual power supplies too often ends up in risky designs.
To safely connect a standard wire to a Prusa I3 Steel, I designed this box.
It holds the plug's connector and a 2-pole switch to allow turning on and off without pulling a plug.

Pirnted in colorless material, internal LEDs easily signal that the printer is powered.

The box solidly clamps to the metal frame of the i3 steel when tightening the screws.

Screw type is cylindrical hex-screws in M3 x 35mm.

Can easily be printed without support.

Printed this in PLA "nature" without color to achieve transparency levels good enough to see the LEDs inside.
Took 3 pieces of LEDs, readily configured to work on 12V - cut from a stripe :-).
Wired the power to the supply unit and 12V back from there to power the LEDs.

description.text: It's a 3D scan of a guineafowl skull. Not the best quality

2D fractal Tree

This creates a TWO DIMENSIONAL tree that can be used in creating laser-cut designs

It is possible to create a 3d extrusion of the tree using the following code:
linear_extrude(height = 5) { trunk(); }

Based on "Procedurally Generated Trees" by steveweber314 on instructables
http://www.instructables.com/id/Procedurally-Generated-Trees/

to use from with an OpenSCAD design:

use </path/to/this/file/fractal_tree.scad>

call with:
trunk();

paramaters:

size = [real] Base size for the trunk
depth = [integer 0:1] Number of recursions (warning: /exponentially more
opperations per increase of depth
seed = [real>0] Random seed to base tree on
widthBottom = [real 0:1] Width of bottom of each segment as a proportion of size
widthTop = [real 0:1] Width of top of each segment a s aproportion of size
joint = [real 0:1] Size of joint as percentage of size
minGrowth = [real 0.1:1.2] Minimum amount to grow branch as percentage of previous
maxGrowth = [real 0.1:1.2] Maximum amount to grow branch as precentage of previous
leafScale = [real 0.1:1] Radius of leaf as a percentage of branch size
leaf = [boolean true:false] True: include leaves, False: skip leaves

BE ADVISED: The model I provide with a hole is too small to fit on the X-Grip if you're printing with a rigid material! I printed mine in flex to mimic the "squishiness" of the OEM rubber feet and made the hole slightly too small so my replacement part would have a very tight grip on the metal. Do not expect that part to fit if you print with anything other than a flexible filament.

I should be adding another model soon with a hole appropriately sized for a rigid material.

I lost one of the feet to my RAM Mounts X-Grip phone holder. I use the mount on my bicycle, so it's pretty crucial to holding the phone in place.

I printed this in flex filament with limited infill, just enough to leave the walls squishy. My flex filament is actually pretty hard, so your mileage may vary and you'll have to play with the settings to get it right.

Provided are the files with and without a hole. You probably want to print the one with a hole, but the one without is provided in case you want to remix it with a larger opening. Or contact me if you just can't make it fit and I'll rework it for you.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

10%

Designed using photo modeling. I drew an SVG path over an image of the object, imported the SVG to Blender, converted the curve to a mesh, and used the spin tool to make the 3D mesh. I used TinkerCAD to add the hole.

description.text:
Hi Guys
This is the Rat King hand cannon from Destiny 2.
I'll warn you now this isn't for the faint hearted. Your printer and slicer will need to have it's supports well dialled in as the top section needs a lot and there are very delicate bits that are easy to snap off accidentally.
I did the best I could to simulate the handle covering but you could go over it with the cloth bands if your a perfectionist.
The magazine is fixed as is the trigger.
This thing is very large at nearly 400mm (15") in length. I can only assume that Destiny Characters have really big hands......
As always, tip me if you like my stuff and check out my facebook page Bigbangcollectables for more cool models

comments.text: Love the design! How did you achieve the paint effect on the 'metal' part of the upper handle?
comments.author: Hobbit2513

comments.text:
It was sprayed with gunmetal colour and left to dry. Then a loosely balled sheet of clingfilm (or saran wrap if your from the other side of the pond) was lightly dipped onto some silver paint spread out on a board. Then you lightly dab the film onto the surface. I think its called marbling and there are a few videos on youtube explaining the principle.
If you mess up just clean it off and try again.
Good luck!

print_settings.Notes:: Fit the other end of the belt into the slider's gripper, insert the screw and test-fit the slider in the main body's dovetail slot You will probably need to trim the belt until the slider just reaches the main body. Then, when you tighten the M4 screw all the way the tension will be perfect.

description.text:
This is an improved X axis tensioner and belt gripper, simply bolts onto the back of the x axis carriage using the existing holes.

The belt fits into the gripper slots, then you just tighten the slider screw to tension the belt. Simple.

You will need:
4x M3x18mm screws (use the two that are currently holding the belt, should be a few more left over from the build).
1x M4x30mm screw.
1x M4 half nut.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Print the main body with the longest face on the bed. The gripper slots should be uppermost.

Print the slider on end, so the end with the slot and screw hole is facing up.

I used PLA for this, but if you want to use ABS then you have to allow for shrinkage.

It is very important that the belt is a good fit in the gripper slots. Test by inserting the end of the belt (a scrap piece will do) and pulling hard. If you need to adjust the gripper size, use the 'Horizontal Expansion' setting in Cura. +-0.1mm might be necessary.

Insert the half-nut into the slot, fit one end of the belt into the gripper slot, screw the main body onto the back of the carriage.

Fit the other end of the belt into the slider's gripper, insert the screw and test-fit the slider in the main body's dovetail slot You will probably need to trim the belt until the slider just reaches the main body. Then, when you tighten the M4 screw all the way the tension will be perfect.

comments.text:
This is a great design and works flawlessly!
Before i printed this I was skeptical that the belt would fit and also stay in. I was happily proven wrong.
I printed mine using PLA with a 0.2 layer height and a 60% infill and this thing is sturdy.

title: Titan Aero and BLTouch Mount for Makerfarm Pegasus

description.text:
Mounts an E3D Titan Aero to a MakerFarm Pegasus, optionally with a BLTouch attached to either the left or right side of the mount.

I have provided STL files for 21mm, 26mm and 48mm NEMA 17 motor length. If you are using E3D's Titan Motor then the 26mm version will fit perfectly. The mount attaches to the Pegasus' Carriage with 12mm M5 bolts.

If you need a mount for a different length motor or wish to use different length mounting screws, open the OnShape document and change the value to your requirements. I have exposed the motor length and mount bolt length as variables so they can be easily changed.

I use the left mounted BLTouch version and the Marlin probe offsets are X: +47mm and Y: -28mm.

I also use FDM_Guru's Aero part cooling fan mount for my part cooling needs.

MarkerFarm Pegasus 10"

remixed_from.title: Taranis Pistola: A pistol grip RC controller with a Taranis QX7 inside!

title: Expansion of the Taranis Pistola: A pistol grip RC controller

description.text:
I think the Taranis Pistola by Eficker is one bloody brilliant idea. Not just for those of us who don't get the hang of driving surface vehicles with sticks, but as a system to replace most other pistol style transmitters when it comes to channels and fine tuning options.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2552696
The original design is only lacking 3 things that I am trying to add to it.

1.) Support for the 2nd Gimbal
2.) Having the 4th trim rocker switch
3.) being able to use the JR Module Extension.

As a first Step I've tried to modify the back plate so it can accept 3 new add on designs by providing 3 different kind of mounting options with the ability to route wires through them.

Changes to the Backplate so far are:
1.) Cloned the 3rd Rocker Switch location for the 4th
2.) Added a Mounting Spot on the left side
3.) Added a Mounting Spot on the right side
4.) Added a Mounting Spot behind the pcb.
5.) Freed up the rear mounting spots to be able to screw into them from the outside

The JR Module Bay is based off of dmyers7 Design.
I've modfied the Backplate so it can be mounted directly to the back of the Taranis Pistola.
It will use the lower Mounting holes of the PCB and will not block the Rocker switches or the Antenna Outlet. I don't know how to mount the cables yet, but I will figure that out eventually. The Bay itself is now securable via 2 screws to the backplate.

This Thing is a purely theoretical thing at the moment, and very much WIP since I haven't yet received my X7 and the other parts are still not done printing. So I have no clue if it will even fit where I have placed the mounting spots. You've been warned :-)

title: LWC DIY 6000mAH power Bank 2Amp output
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
UPDATE:09.11.2017 Battery status button was missaligned, corrected that.
Added mechanical button directly to the Case cover.
Added percentage numbers next to battery stats LEDs
Added LWC Logo
Added groove to base for Version2 charging board ( better fit)

Two colors?! Dual extruder?! NO!! I simply paused the print, changed filament and resumed, works pretty nice dont you think?!

Simple DIY Powerbank build. ( Measurment 140x73x16)

Pretty funny story. A friend of mine came along with a powerbank he bought for like supercheap online. 20000mAH was the deal but he complained he couldnt charge his phone over 25%. He handed me the powerbank and I imidiately had to smirk, it was so damn light no way this powerbank would be able to deliver 20000mAH. After opening it up I found a tiny 600mAH lithium battery glued to the case XD They didnt even bother to glue some heavy bolts or nuts to the case to increase the weight.
The circuit board was ok and I was able to find it pretty quickly online. It could deliver up to 2amps so thats not to bad at all.
From an earlier fraud I still had a 6000mAH battery some shop tried to fool me for a 10000mAH battery.
So it was time to finally transform two frauds into a happy ending.

The powerbank outputs almost 2 amps and really does charge your electronics pretty fast ;)
it also features 4 LEDs showing the charge in 25%, 50%, 75% and 100%.
A single white LED mini flashlight ( by pressing and holding the button)

Things you need:

Lipo Battery 6000mAH:

https://de.aliexpress.com/item/Free-shipping-Polymer-battery-6000-mah-3-7V-906090-smart-home-MP3-speakers-Li-ion-battery/32775287429.html

Lipo Battery 10000mAH:

https://de.aliexpress.com/item/1pc-8573130-3-7V-10000mAh-Lithium-Polymer-LiPo-3-7v-10ah-Rechargeable-Battery-2a-For-power/32709430864.html

Powerbank circuit board:

https://de.aliexpress.com/item/5V1A-2A-Mobile-Power-Bank-Charger-Module-Step-Up-Power-Boost-Supply-Circuit-PCB-Board-Charging/32807277124.html

Some superglue, hotglue gun, soldering iron
You can of course try to fit a bigger battery inside, but as I only had one I added some padding to make the battery shockproof.

!!ATTENTION!! Never use a unprotected lithium ion or lipo battery!
Always pay attention to buy a protected battery ( tiny circuit board directly soldered to the battery, from the protection circuit board the + and - cable emerge)

title: jjrc h31 to 808 mini hd-camera (#16) board adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
this is a quick-n-dirty adapter to mechanically mount the board of an 808-16 keychain hd-camera upside down to the belly of a jjrc-h31 drone.

the drone already has 4 little posts to mount something on. you will need 4 tiny srews to fix the adapter there.
the adapter has itself 3 posts for the 808-board.
note: I have no holes printed in those, as the screws are really tiny. instead I used a needle and a lighter, to burn tiny holes into them, so that the original 808-screws fit quite well.

the adapter itself isn't very stiff - it get's its stiffness from the mount to the drone and from the mount to the 808-board.

oh, I didn't use the original key-chain housing at all, as it comes with weight and only little functionality (like of course protection) - but the most important for me was to loose weight (on the drone ;-).

I glued the lens with a double-sided foam tape to the platform I introduced in front of the adapter. this way, the lens is a bit stabilized and has an angle of about 30° downwards. additionally you can wrap some tape around the lens and the platform, if you think the mechanical connection through the tape is too weak.

you will see, that the original battery will not fit in here - I introduced a jjrc-h31 backup-battery as the "new" 808-battery. it lasts longer and fits well on the back part of the adapter, with a little elastic band to fix it there.

as promised, here you are some pictures of the final assembly. I also introduced some foam below the lens-area to reduce vibrations. this works nicely - not to say perfect - while hovering - in flight i do have some vibrations.

one last thing: if you open the lens, you can easily remove the ir-filter, which makes it a real cool ir-camera with a little better lowlight performance - if you can accept the reds in your movies ;-). of course you have to adapt the focus a little then.

title: rugged airport buckle with 2-color logo on a single color printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
after trying a lot of airport-buckle designs, I decided to come up with my own. the ones I found were either difficult to print and/or too fragile, so they would break way too easily - while you need to rely on your belt especially while travelling.

so here's the rugged one ;-) tested by myself on quite a few occasions.

It comes with a double-5mm-pin (so you have to make double holes in your belt) and with 2 double-5mm-posts to attach the belt the buckle. the belt is then secured to the buckle with a clip, which can be inserted from one side behind the belt. this way, no plastic screw is needed, which is usually the first thing to break.

printing is quite simple - the only part where you need a support (the pin) already has a buildt in support to break away. of course your printer should be able to do bridges...

now comes the fun part: I introduced a 1mm-thick logo on top of the belt - or better - a 1mm hole of a logo ;-) if you print in 0,2mm resolution, you can change filament colors in layers 80 and 85 (on my marlin-printer, this is supported with the M600 command) and you'll get a nice colored logo on a single color printer ;-). Yes, you'll have to manually enter the M600 command into the gcode-file - but that shouldn't be too difficult.

on the picture you can see a version I made for shark24-sailors, with the shark24 logo and even with an engraved shark24-text on top.

as an example I uploaded a version with a mustang logo. thx to logdog16 for his logo: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:299087

if you want to do your on, just fill the top 1mm solidly and then subtract a 1mm logo from it - or send me a message ;-).

Prusa

Prusa Clone

author: megic

title: Smooth Q gimbal action camera mount

description.text:
My gimbal action camera mount allows me to attach my Eken H9R to my Smooth Q gimbal. No special print settings needed and no supports. I designed it so that 3mm x 30mm screws could be threaded through the front of the cross member and use 3mm nuts to attach the cross member to the mounting plate. The mount is designed to allow the camera to be mounted left or right origination. I printed two small knobs from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1230280, to make it easier to use and so they didn't cover the screen. I wanted mine to be able to be assembled/disassembled without tools when being used.

Update - added photos of my camera mounted in the other orientation as the gimbal could be seen by the camera. Press mode button three times to make the gimbal do a 180 degree turn.

description.text:
Infection Express (Designed by Andy Oakey) is a compact, 1-2 player dice game inspired by Pandemic. Using 5 dice instead of the many cards of the original game, it is much quicker to play, whilst maintaining the tension. title: Tevo Tarantula sg90 servo auto leveling
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
To use a servo and endstop for auto leveling on a Tevo Tarantula with fan fang I designed a servo mount. It is not pretty but works well. It is fastened using 2 out of the 4 screws that mount the hotend to the x-carriage.

The servo arm is a shorter version of the arm designed by MacNite. Also, see his version for a guide how to set up the servo (it is not 100% correct but its a good start, the comments in Marlin will help you further).

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

You have to turn the servo mount 90 degrees around the x-axis for the easiest way to print it. Support is needed for a good result.

Change the firmware to enable auto leveling

MacNite has a fairly good guide to enable and setup auto leveling, some parameter or setting names are different depending on the Marlin version. Read the Marlin comments, they will tell you enough to know what setting is needed.

Also the metal clip on the endstop may cause the endstop/leveling offset to change a lot due to fatigue. It might be recommended to remove the clip.

• SG90 servo (and the accessoires)

  • Printed parts (arm + servo mount)

  • A working Marlin version to enable auto leveling

Notes:

We wound up printing these with no infill and 5 layers. This allowed them to flex without breaking... for the most part. Time was short so this was a rush to get it done job.. We had a few failures but most came out great..

comments.text: Contrary to what others have told me, I would not make them out of PLA again.  PETG perhaps.. The PLA is not holding tension like it should over time.  The clips around the EMT are becoming looser as time goes on.  it is not a design issue me thinks.. but rather a materials issue.

title: Tzaar - Playing Piece
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
TZAAR is a game about making choices. Both players have 30 pieces, divided in three types: 6 Tzaars, 9 Tzarras and 15 Totts. The aim is either to make the opponent run out of one of the three types of pieces or to put him in a position in which he cannot capture anymore. The tricky question the players will have to ask themselves on each of their turns is: “Shall I make myself stronger or my opponent weaker?” Meaning: Will you capture an opponent’s piece and make him weaker, or will you jump on top of one of your own pieces and make yourself stronger?
Here a playing piece for this challenging game.
Print and Paint.

title: Samsung wireless charger - docking station v2

description.text:
This is an updated version of my first design. Which looks better in my opinion and saves a bit of material and printing time. The printing settings are the same as the previous version.
I had to swap the material during printing, because I ran out of black material. The white CPE came out nicely as extra design addition.

Keep in mind that the usb-port gap size is now smaller. It will probably be too small for most bulky usb connectors. The original Samsung usb-cable connector fits nicely the way it is now, preventing the wireless charger from rotating a bit in the dock.

The first version, for reference, can be found in the following link:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2551349

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20-25%

Notes:
  • Supports usage is just for the USB-port opening. If possible (as in Simplefy3d) set the infill angle to the maximum of 89 degrees to prevent support generation in the air gap sides.
  • No Brim needed, just a skirt is enough.
  • Printed in PLA 208 Celsius degrees nozzle 0.4mm.
  • Printed in CPE 252 Celsius degrees nozzle 0.4mm with gluestick(and kapton tape in my case).
  • Fans at 80% ~5th layer with CPE, PLA can be at 80-100%. I tend to set it to 80% or so for noise reduction. Setting the speed higher, does not seem to affect the printing that much.
  • 11.3m filament with 7 hours 20 minutes printing time.
The STL is generated on the side, but I printed this with the gaps underneath. Rotate the object 90 degrees before printing!

description.text:

title: Cyclops-Chimera Mount for 2 Nimbles on an original D-Bot and the 3-Wheeled X-Carriage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mount for 2 single Nimbles.
Please don't confuse this with the "D-Bot Chimera/Cyclops adapter for the Dual Nimble using the printingSome carriage", https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2459458.

I chose to buy 2 single Nimbles because perhaps I will try them later with a diamond hot end and then only have to buy 1 extra.

You won't need the "Groove Adapters" provided with the Nimbles. These would overlap each other in this arrangement. Part1 will replace them.

Part 2a is to be used with my "3-wheeled Modular X-carriage (D-Bot Core-XY 3D Printer)", https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2206664
Part 2b is to be used with the original front plate of the "D-Bot Core-XY 3D Printer" by spauda01, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001065.
I did not print the last one, but have no reason to believe there would be problems. Please let me know if you find otherwise.

The 2 parts fit together with the nimbles using the M3x40 bolts in the package.
The whole thing can be mounted on the front plate with 4 M3x10 bolts + washers. I like to use serrated lock washers too.

You can then easily (dis)mount the chimera/cyclops with 3 M3x8 bolts + washers and ditto.

No support, thanks to the 2-part solution. Printed part1 not at all perfectly with 0.15mm layers, but a little tlc made it fit ok. Please check whether the nimbles stand firm on the mounting plate.

Cutting the teflon tubes 11mm above the chimera/cyclops should set them flush against the nimble.

Edit (11/10/17) I couldn't find a way to mount the stepper motors without losing printing space, so I made a Nimble_Stepper_Mount, see
3-wheeled or Linear Railed Modular X-carriage (D-Bot Core_XY 3D Printer) by printingSome, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2206664

remixed_from.author: frol
remixed_from.title: Y belt attachment for Anet A8-B printer

description.text:
The original part seemed a bit loose, and I eventually got round to investigating. My belt measures 1.7 mm over the teeth, 1.2 mm in the teeth. Although the short section in the original looks OK, the long section is 0.5mm too wide.

The remix ix the 4mm version, with the 2nd path made narrower where the two belts overlap. The other end is slightly tighter, but relaxed a little so it doesn't push the belt sideways.

I have also split off one of the mountings to act as a retainer, and provided a small 'test fit' part which you can use to test against your belt. Both slots need to fit :)

Use either the 'simple', or 'base + fixing' parts.

First time round, i got far too tight a fit. Will wait till i have a new belt before fitting the replacement (the old belts looking a bit ragged after a year).Tweaked again 9 Oct 2017 for slightly easier fit.

title: Presentation Case for Kershaw Chive Pocket Knife

description.text: This is a hinged lid, magnetic closure presentation case for a Kershaw Chive pocket knife. I gave a pair of these knives to the twin sons of a very close friend of mine and I wanted to make a special box for them. The lid of the box had the boys initials but the version I uploaded is blank so it will be more useful to you. If desired, you could add text or other embellishment to the lid with Meshmixer.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used wood PLA for mine. Orient the parts on the build plate with the cavity facing up.

There is a fair amount of work to do after printing. The hinges require 1/16" pins of brass or steel. I had some 1/16" stainless steel welding rod on hand so I used that. Clean up the holes with a 1/16" drill bit first. The magnets are 2mm x 1mm. Available here: https://www.banggood.com/100pcs-N50-2mm-x-1mm-Round-Magnets-Rare-Earth-Neodymium-NdFeB-p-942082.html?rmmds=search
They are secured with a bit of superglue (cyanoacrylate). To add a little class, I lined the cavity for the knife with black velvet. Contact cement worked well for this and to accommodate the clip on the back of the knife, I placed some 1/8" foam rubber pad in the bottom of the cavity before applying the velvet. The cavity for the knife is oversize to allow for the velvet liner.

I am a noob when it comes to computer assisted design. I struggled with the recessed feature for the knife and ultimately used a method found on Youtube that utilizes a photo of the knife that is calibrated in SolidWorks. If I actually knew what I was doing, it probably would have taken only a couple of minutes. Oh well, life is a learning experience.

print_settings.Notes:: Print two center spars and clean up as necessary to get a tight fit into the mating holes in the beam halves.  Super-glue all the parts together and paint if you want some more realistic colors.  I stuck with the White, Pink and Silver PLA to keep a Barbie toy like theme.

description.text:
My daughter asked for a Barbie Gymnastics set from Target for her birthday. After purchasing the one she wanted (https://www.target.com/p/barbie-174-careers-gymnastic-coach-dolls-playset/-/A-52607245#lnk=sametab) and realizing how lack-luster it was, I decided I could do better. The result is this Balance Beam, a Pommel Horse and a Spring Board to make a nice DIY playset.

Pommel Horse: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2574942
Spring Board: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2576832

This is a nice, fairly scale size balance beam that can be printed in three sizes in case you have a small print bed. You can also mix and match to get a finished length that fits your needs.

I printed the beam in the same position it gets used in. This required me to use supports to keep the pockets for the legs supported. You could easily print upside-down or even vertically if you were brave. I've included a small Beam Half Test Piece if you want to experiment before committing to the full print.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The legs will curl off the print bed if you don't use a brim. 3mm worked perfectly for me. Supports only needed on the Beam Half if you choose to print in the orientation that I supplied the STL in.

Print two center spars and clean up as necessary to get a tight fit into the mating holes in the beam halves. Super-glue all the parts together and paint if you want some more realistic colors. I stuck with the White, Pink and Silver PLA to keep a Barbie toy like theme.

Test piece

Use this extra short test piece if you want to experiment with print orientation and supports before committing to the full print.

Beam Half Test.stl Use 3mm brim on legs

The contact area of the cross piece is so small, the part will curl off the print bed and ruin your print if you don't add a brimm. I used 3mm and it worked perfectly!

These were the initial prints, decided to add the cross bracing for strength later as you see in the final STL's Feet added just for looks. They print quickly and can be snapped or glued on. Inspiration shot from Google search My finished design in the same orientation and rendered in Fusion 360. Another inspiration shot in almost my same planned colors. My finished design in the same orientation and rendered in Fusion 360.

Inspirational set can be purchased here:
https://www.target.com/p/barbie-174-careers-gymnastic-coach-dolls-playset/-/A-52607245#lnk=sametab

Another inspirational set that can be purchased here:
https://www.amazon.com/Barbie-Toddler-Student-Flippin-Gymnastics/dp/B01ARGBRGW/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1507468224&sr=8-3&keywords=barbie+gymnastic

I designed this Indestructible Frame to overcome some basic "weak-spots" that usually appear on micro frames especially around the motors. The length diagonally from prop to prop is around 120mm and it supports FC's with dimensions such as L: 37.04 , W: 24.02mm. The frame has to be used with 8520 motors and your own choice of props althouugh I am going to use some King Kong 65mm props as soon as I have this printed. There is also a slot at the back of the FC for easier use with FC's that have rear USB ports and battery leads.

Parts I will be using:
Eachine AIOF3_BRUSHED Flight Control Board Built-in OSD Frsky Receiver.
4X Racerstar 8520 8.5x20mm 53500RPM Coreless Motors.
10 Pairs Kingkong 65mm Blade Propellers.
Eachine TX05 Camera with OSD AIO mW switchable between 0.01-250mW.
Turnigy Nano-Tech 750mAh 35-70C Battery.

Wish you the best of luck and please keep me up to date on your experience with this frame..

print_settings.Notes:: Printed at 125% size

description.text:
Hi there!

This is the printable Version of the basic tank from Planetary Annihilation called "Bolo" previously, now "Ant". More to read below....

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

15% - 20%

Notes:

Printed at 125% size

Features

All parts simply slide into each other. When printed at 125% the gap between the parts is theoratically 0.125mm wide. This means that the parts should fit without much afterwork, but still stay together while the Tank is turned upside down. I only used glue to keep the headlights inside the casing. Other than these the tank can be dis- and reassembled at any time.

The Turret is connected with the Body by a printed screw, which is accessible from the bottom. It is meant to be screwed all the way in, as the Screw is ~0.5mm longer. Therefor the Screw will stay in place while the Turret can be turned with low friction.

The cannon can be turned up and down, the angle depends on how you push it into the Turret. It is squeezed inbetween two knobs. I did print the Cannon_Base with fitting indentations, however the cannon did not lock in place anymore.

Supports are not needed at all, as all seperate parts have flat surfaces, print them as you like. I already added larger first layer surfaces on some parts that are especially endangered to suffer from warping.

Background stuff

The color scheme does not quite match the original, but I did my best at splitting the colors into seperate parts.

I completely reconstructed the 3D-model based off Schtekarn's upload (thing:700941) who extracted the model from the official game. Thanks, by the way!

Tell me your Experiences!

Constructive Criticism, Recommendations and wished Changes/Expansions are highly appreciated! Share your thoughts in the comments!

If you printed this, please share it. I am really looking forward to your color combinations!

It was quite a lot of work and I hope you like it!
Happy printing!

comments.text: Thanks! Tell me what you would like to print, I will see what I can do ;) But I will stay with the rather basic models, I think
comments.author: Lee_Besley

comments.text: Reminds me a lot of the vehicles from the previous game, Total Annihilation. Great work!

description.text: 360mm outer diameter. Use 2 pieces of bearings 608 and 8mm threaded rod as axis. Main costruction part are screwed with m4 threaded rods and M4 nuts. No

No

0.25

Infill:

20%-100%

Notes:

Can by printed from any construction material. I personally preffer ABS.
Just remove (cut off) small technological pads from 12pcs printed parts.

Its new version of previous mounted spool with M4, instead m8 threaded rods.
BOM:
2x ... stred civky
12x ... civka obruc
12x ... M4 x 115mm threaded rod

1x ... M8 x 300mm threaded rod

(optionally 12x 100mm nylon filament for spool break)

title: Adjustable bracket for EK Revo D5 holder 120 mm fan

description.text:
Hi,

this is a modified version of my fan bracket for clamp style mounts for reservoirs. This variant is designed to mount the EK Revo D5 holder and you can adjust the position of the pump holder from the bottom or the top (dependung on which side is up) to the middle.

Unfortunately I don't have a possibility to print this (nor do I need one myself) so if you have suggestions on how to improve it please let me know.

comments.text: I like this bracket design.  i used a variant of it that had points throughout the channel that would make the mounting channel stronger.  I own the factory EK bracket and my plan buying this bracket was to have the ability to lower the mounting point of the pump, and because the 3d printed bracket LOOKED thinner than the factory EK one I thought I would gain more clearance in my pc.  I was wrong.  This bracket is only about a half mm thinner than the factory bracket.
comments.author: SpecterM

comments.text: Is there any chance you could design this without the feet?  I need it to be as thin as possible.
comments.author: SpecterM

comments.text: Hi, sure, that would be possible, but the problem will be, that the screws, that you use to mount the pump holder to the bracket, stick out a bit so that mounting the bracket to the fan flush might be impossible. Can you tell me the diameter and the height of the screwheads that you'll be using? I will have to incorporate a recess for them in the slots to countersink the screws.
comments.author: SpecterM

remixed_from.title: Electric Skateboard Wheel Guard / Mud Guard

title: Electric Skateboard Wheelguard (without Hex Nut Insert)

description.text:
I removed the hex nut insert for better scalability.
At 85% scale they fit perfectly for 70 mm wheels.

Installation:
Heat up the threaded ending of the truck with a lighter an then screw them on.

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

0%

comments.text:
Hi Sebastian, Thanks for the remix!
The hex nut insert was incorporated into the design for a very good reason.
Without the nut insert the whole guard will rotate and can end up under the wheels (very scary this happened to me!).
After this happened I adjusted the design to include the nut insert to stop the guards from being able to rotate which made them much safer.
comments.author: jdnicholson

comments.text:
Hi, thank you for the design. It works really well!
I found the assembly and the support clean up much simpler without the insert.
To prevent it from rotating I heated up the part where the nut touches and then fastened it really tightly. So now there is an indentation which along with the pressure will hinder rotation.
comments.author: jdnicholson

remixed_from.title: Hesine M-505, Anet A8 - Center Nozzle Fan

title: Wades L3K - Adjustable Radial Fan Mount (for Anet A8 Fan shrouds)

description.text:
EDIT: made a stronger version, PLA worked fine before (v3), if printed in PETG or ABS use the final version. Word of warning though, printing the final (stronger) version will partially block access to the hobbed bolt.

Also see this awesome design by floyd871 for adding a bltouch, compatible with this radial fan mount. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2613106

I really liked the "Wade L3K Extruder (prusa i3) compatible filament flexible By Skarab...." https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:512338 but this version doesn't have any nice fan shrouds for radial fans, or any that fit an e3d at all.

But why reinvent the wheel, there are already dozens of radial fan shrouds, i picked one for the Anet A8 a well known and supported printer in this community (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1620630) and made a small and easy radial fan holder that fits the 2 together.

replace the hot end holder's m3 screws with longer ones, and secure this small part together with the hot end mount for the wade L3K. Mount a radial fan and mount your favourite fan shroud for the Anet A8 (any should work).

Adjust to desired height and have fun printing in higher quality.

This is an Arduino Uno + Ethernet shield + Komby NRF Shield (minimalist sheild) + NRF24l01+ amplified wireless transceiver module. It is used primarily for wireless control of Christmas lights (see diychristmas.org) but can be used for OTHER wireless fun! You need to source the pieces (Ebay is a great place for everything except the Komby shield which can be ordered from komby.com). (Note: the pictures are from my prototype run- I've cleaned things up like the Komby name since I took those pictures. 3/25/14 Added "case_komby_top_v3_1" to reduce plastic use on the top. It was a bit too thick and wasteful so I thinned it a bit. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/5Eq4YC6Xhcq if you need to make custom front plate spacing for connectors.

The bottom, top and back are universal.  Ethernet shields can have the connector in different spots- the two most common are included.  Print the four, bolt in your "Komby Sandwich" into the bottom then put on the top, front and back.  I generally print WITHOUT support and it prints well but it depends on your printer I guess.  
Use the case_komby_top_v3_1 if you want to save some plastic by having a thinner top (on the horizontal surface).

print_settings.Notes:: See summary for details

description.text:
This is a trash bin for the BMW i3 that connects to the accessory slots in front of the middle console. I made it to work around the extra cup holder if you keep that in the middle slot.

The accessory slot connector was made with 70% infill for strength. It took less than 2 hours to complete. The bin was made with 20% infill but took a whopping 18 hours to build. I wanted the bin to reach all the way to the floor so there was no stress on the connector. I could have put small feet under the bin to make it smaller and thus less filament but this was my first run at this Thingy

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

See summary for details

This was a trial and error to get the angles correct as well as the distance between the connectors. I wanted to use 2 accessory slots because I wanted it to be strong and secure. I also wasn't sure how to connect the bin to the connector so I ended up deciding on a simple plug that would slide into place

---- UPDATE 14 Nov 2017 ----

New and fixed STL Files are uploaded.

---- UPDATE 12 Nov 2017 ----

Uploaded a new Picture and updating STL Files for reupload.

Always loved the Design of the Gungrave Right- and Lefthead Cerberus Handguns. And with the new Game (GunGrave VR) on the horizon i thought it would be the perfect time to print them. Couldn't really find a 3D Model i was completely happy with so i made one myself.

Uploaded files are all parts for the Right Head (some need to be printed multiple times - screws). For the Left Head Part A1 and A2 need to be mirrored (for safty catch beeing on the correct side).

Model size is optimized for Ultimaker 2+ Print Bed

Also included a complete single part version of the final gun.

Little Screws can be printed or just use DIN 84 M3,5x6mm

Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have a question of any kind.

title: Berd-Air MAX Pump Bracket for Kossel Deltas

description.text:
I whipped this up to neatly mount my Berd-Air pump to the lower frame of my UltiBots Kossel D300VS delta. The bolt hole spacing is 40mm so the bracket can be fastened across the bottom pair of 2020 V-Slot rails with the air tube pointing forward towards the effector "whip" mount.

Position the bracket on the "whip" side of the printer with the clamp portion of the bracket pointing down. Fasten bracket to the pair of 2020 V-Slot rails using two M5 x 8mm cap screws, then slide the pump into place and clamp with a M4 screw and nut. Take note the pump is slid into the clamp far enough to avoid obstructing the commutator cooling holes!

EDIT: I noticed that the pump head was actually slightly touching the frame of my printer, so I changed the design a little to add about 5mm of additional spacing. This should be enough to keep the pump from touching the chassis while still keeping it from hanging off the side too far. Apologies to anyone who printed the first version!

comments.text:
Ciao SgaboLab, mi è arrivata la printer e sto procedendo al montaggio con tutte le tue modifiche, compresa quella dei motori X ed Y anteriori.
L'unica cosa che proprio non mi piace, ma anche ad altri noto da alcuni commenti, è il dover filettare il profilato forandolo (M5), per poter fissare i cuscinetti di radccordo per le cinghie X/Y.
Se la filettatura viene un pò storta c'è il rischio che poi lavorino imbarcate.
Non sarebbe meglio studiare un qualcosa per poterle fissare in altro modo?
Anche un foro passante da 5mm, per poi serrarle con un bullone ed una rondellona nella parte bassa del profilato, non sarebbe più semplice, anche se comunque invasivo?
Non tutti hanno una filettatrice M5, anche se è un attimo procurarsela, più che altro molti non sanno usare al meglio quel tipo di utensili.
Perché non pensi ad un qualcosa d'alternativo, magari usando un doppio t-nuts fissato con due M4, che tengano su il supporto per l'M5 dei cuscinetti?
Son conscio che dev'essere un qualcosa di tremendamente resistente, essendo continuamente sottoposto a trazione, ma un'alternativa meno "trapanosa"? :D
Dal video inoltre si capisce che il foro vuole a 30mm dal bordo del profilato, ma considerando il centro del foro M5 o il bordo dello stesso?

description.text:
My daughter asked for a Barbie Gymnastics set from Target for her birthday. After purchasing the one she wanted (https://www.target.com/p/barbie-174-careers-gymnastic-coach-dolls-playset/-/A-52607245#lnk=sametab) and realizing how lack-luster it was, I decided I could do better. The result is this Pommel Horse, a Spring Board and a Balance Beam to make a nice DIY playset.

Balance Beam: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2574795
Spring Board: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2576832

This is a nice, fairly scale size pommel horse that requires a print bed large enough for the 180mm long body. The legs and feet are identical to the ones used in my Balance Beam design.

The body requires supports to keep the leg pockets from sagging in. The interior has built in ribs to allow for a hollow interior while still supporting the top curve of the body. Note the body took over 10 hours to print but is light weight and didn't waste a ton of filament.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The body is a 10 hour print but is also self supporting internally. Supports only needed to keep the leg pockets open on the bottom. Slic3r added these end supports for who knows what reason. Who am I to complain though I guess as the print came out absolutely perfectly.

Body with minimal supports needed. Use 3mm brim on legs

The contact area of the cross piece is so small, the part will curl off the print bed and ruin your print if you don't add a brimm. I used 3mm and it worked perfectly!

These were the initial prints, decided to add the cross bracing for strength later as you see in the final STL's Feet added just for looks. They print quickly and can be snapped or glued on. Handles and alignment pegs Glue optional

While the handles are designed to be CA glued together, I found that with the alignment pins installed, they friction fit perfectly into the body so no glue was needed to hold the halves together nor was it necessary to glue the handles into the body. While I'll probably glue the handle assembly together, I think I'll leave them friction fit into the body and thus removable. That way if I can figure out a few other handle configurations that allow for posing the dolls and locking their arms into the handles, then you can freely swap out as needed. Watch this space for potential future updates.

Pommel Horse Body Test

As noted, the body is a 10 hour print! Use this smaller test piece for any experimentation you may need prior to the final print. This piece took about 3hrs and 43min on my Prusa.

Note that body is largely hollow so you aren't wasting tons of filament on infill. I added a series of internal ribs that print without support and give the top something to bridge across without needing infill.

Inspirational pic from Google search My finished design in a similar orientation and rendered in Fusion 360.
Fusion 360

title: Rubberband Crossbow - Easy Assembly and Compact

description.text:
This is an improved version of the crossbow by Tech2C.

You can shoot pencils, pens, pieces of paper and other things using this very neat little rubberband powered crossbow!

This is an excellent crossbow that is

  • Compact (you can quickly deconstruct it and put it in your pocket)
  • Easy to assemble (Push, click, and you're done)
  • Powerful (I can shoot IKEA pencils up to 10 meters away)
  • Strong (It won't break easily)
  • Proven (I have printed 6 of these now to give away and all of them work very good!)

It is printable with printers than have a max print size 120x120 mm. (rotate the bow part 45 degrees to fit)

See it in action:

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

20%

Notes:

No supports needed. Resolution can be rough, that should not be a problem.

This model has a high tolerance in the mehcanical parts. Some printers such as mine, always seem to print models a little thicker than how they were intended, so most of the stuff I get from Thingiverse doesn't fit and I have to edit those to be more tolerant. This model is already tolerant so nobody has those issues! :)

Operating in action. 1. Insert the two trigger parts onto the main body 2. Add a small elastic band in the way shown in this picture 3. push the cover on top of the main body. 4. put the bow in the bow slot 5. Done!

Just to show I despise all politicians equally I present to you...HILLABLO!

It turns out good ole Hillary really is a bitch. I could not get the Boolean Merge to work no matter what I tried so I ended up doing a combine. If you have S3D you'll need to separate connected surfaces before printing. I can't speak for other slicers.

Have Fun!

E

Update: Well it looks like this Model is a Simplify 3D killer. I tried Separate Connected Surfaces and ended up with over 20 objects. Unfortunately the program keeps bombing when I preview the G-code for printing. I tried loading it into Cura 15 and although the parsing was slow it looks like it can handle the Model. I'll be looking into Cura 2.7 to see if that works also.

description.text:
For those of us that live in apartments and can not drill into the walls; i made a towel rack that hangs above a sink.
All the ones i found needed to drill or stick something to the cabinets or walls and i don't like doing that with rentals so i made one that it all friction based.
I also wanted something that would hang over the sink so the towels drip in an existing basin and not on a counter or a tray that gets moldy.

The clamps are from this thing
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1673030
and i made the arms fit around them with the plate and chopstick cutouts.
I only use half of the cheap poly carbonate chopsticks in the holes but you can use anything you want really. I just had them laying around.

Note the rounded corner cube int he scad file doesn't work in the z axis there are ones out there that do work. FYI.

description.text:
Ich habe dem Schaltergehäuse etwas mehr Tiefe gegeben damit auch die Verkabelung vernünftig passt.
Das Gehäuse ist jetzt für Schalter mit den Abmaßen 19mm x 12,5mm (Coverabdeckung 21mm x 15mm) und einer Tiefe von bis zu 28mm geeignet.

Es ist ein Remix von https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:105692

English:
I gave the switch housing a little more depth so that the wiring fits well.
The housing is now suitable for switches with the dimensions 19mm x 12.5mm (cover cover 21mm x 15mm) and a depth of up to 28mm.

It´s a Remix from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:105692
